lines.content: toolVersion = '11.0.0' // Match this version in IntelliJ
GOODDAY AND GOODNIGHT. THIS IS BURGER.
BURGER STEALS YOUR TASKS AND MANAGES THEM.
HERE'S HOW YOU CAN BURGER YOUR TASKS:
Adds a simple task to your list.
Adds a task with a deadline.
Adds an event with a start and end time.
Shows all tasks with their status and type.
3. Mark Tasks as Done or Not Done
Marks the task as not done.
Removes the task from your list.
Saves your tasks and exits the program.
- Tasks are automatically saved to disk whenever you add, delete, or update them.
- If you run BURGER for the first time, it will create a storage file automatically.
- BURGER ignores corrupted lines in the storage file, so your other tasks remain safe.
* Command to add a deadline task to the task list.
* The command expects input in the format: (description) /by (deadline)

ui.showMessage("BURGER ADDED: " + deadline + "\nNOW YOU HAVE " + tasks.size() + " TASK(S).");
throw new BurgerException("BURGER ERROR: Invalid date format! Use yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");
* Command to add an event task to the task list.
* The command expects input in the format: (description) /from (start time) /to (end time).
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT_FORMAT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");

throw new BurgerException("BURGER ERROR: Event must have a description and /from time.");
LocalDateTime to = toStr.isEmpty() ? null : LocalDateTime.parse(toStr, INPUT_FORMAT);
Event event = new Event(description, from, to);
ui.showMessage("BURGER ADDED: " + event + "\nNOW YOU HAVE " + tasks.size() + " TASK(S).");
throw new BurgerException("BURGER ERROR: Invalid date/time format! Use yyyy-MM-dd HHmm");

* Handles the loading and saving of {@link TaskList} data to a local file.
* Each task is serialized into a line in the file, and the Storage class is responsible
* for reading that file and reconstructing {@link Task} objects, as well as writing
* updated task data back to the file.
* Constructs a Storage object that manages a specific file path.
* @param filePath the file path where tasks will be loaded from and saved to
* Loads the task list from the file specified in {@link #FILE_PATH}.
* If the file or its parent directories do not exist, they will be created automatically,
* and an empty {@link TaskList} will be returned.
* @return a {@link TaskList} containing tasks loaded from the file
* @throws BurgerException if there is an I/O error while reading the file
